TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants , who are NORP nationals , have both lived in GPE since DATE . They were married in GPE in DATE and PERSON has NORP citizenship also . In accordance with NORP law ( LAW ) , they chose the wife ’s surname , " PERSON " , as their family name ; the husband availed himself of his right to put his own surname in front of that and thus call himself " PERSON " .

CARDINAL . The NORP registry office ( GPE ) having recorded " Schnyder " as their joint surname , the couple applied to substitute " PERSON " as the family surname and " PERSON " as the husband ’s surname . On DATE the cantonal government ( NORP ) of GPE turned down the application .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants made a further application to the cantonal ORG ) of ORG , following an amendment to LAW as regards the effects of marriage , which had been made on DATE and had come into force on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

On DATE their application was again refused , on the ground that they had not pointed to any serious inconvenience arising from the use of the surname " PERSON " . Furthermore , in the absence of any transitional provisions the new LAW para . CARDINAL of LAW could not apply to couples married before DATE . Lastly , under the new LAW para . CARDINAL , only a wife could put her own surname before the family name ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . The applicants then lodged an appeal ( GPE ) with ORG ( PERSON ) in which they complained of , among other things , a breach of the new LAW and CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of LAW and LAW para . CARDINAL of LAW ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL below ) .

On DATE ORG allowed the appeal in part . While refusing to apply paragraph CARDINAL of Article CARDINAL , which concerned only engaged couples and had no retrospective effect , it held that in the particular case there were important factors which justified applying paragraph CARDINAL in order to allow the applicants to call themselves " Burghartz " ; apart from DATE and profession , account had to be taken of the differences between the relevant NORP and NORP systems , which were made more acute by the fact that PERSON was a frontier city .

As to Mr PERSON ’s application to be allowed to bear the name " PERSON " , no support for it could be found in LAW para . CARDINAL of LAW ; the drafting history showed that ORG , out of a concern to preserve family unity and avoid a break with tradition , had never agreed to introduce absolute equality between spouses in the choice of name and had thus deliberately restricted to wives the right to add their own surnames to their husbands’ . This rule therefore could not avail by analogy a husband in a family known by the wife ’s surname . There was , however , nothing to prevent Mr PERSON from using a double - barrelled name ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) or even , informally , putting his surname before his wife ’s .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant , a large number of official documents , in particular the certificate of his doctorate in history , had not since then contained the " Schnyder " element of his surname .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of the Swiss Federal LAW provides :
" Men and women shall have equal rights . Equality shall be provided for by law , in particular in relation to the family , education and work ... "
CARDINAL . The relevant new Civil Code provisions that came into force on DATE read as follows :
" ( CARDINAL ) The government of the canton of residence may , if there is good cause , authorise a person to change his or her name .
( CARDINAL ) Engaged couples shall be authorised , if they so request and if they prove a legitimate interest , to bear the wife ’s surname as the family name once the marriage has been solemnised .
" ( CARDINAL ) Married couples shall take the husband ’s surname as their family name .
( CARDINAL ) A bride may , however , make a declaration to the registrar that she wishes to keep the surname she has borne to date , followed by the family name .
" ( CARDINAL ) The children of married couples shall bear their family name .

" Within DATE of the entry into force of the new Act , a woman who was married under the old law may make a declaration to the registrar that she wishes to put the surname she bore before her marriage in front of the family name . "

CARDINAL . By a custom recognised in case - law , married couples may also put the wife ’s surname after the husband ’s surname , joining the CARDINAL with a hyphen . This double - barrelled name ( Allianzname ) , however , is not regarded as the legal family name ( ORG , judgment of CARDINAL DATE , Judgments of ORG , vol . CARDINAL II CARDINAL ) .
